commentBody: 10x easier than yesterday‚Äôs puzzle.

Sam,
32A ORD *is* short for ordinal.

An ordinal number is a number that tells the position of something in a list, such as 1st, 2nd, 3rd, 4th, 5th and so on.
A fun and clever puzzle!
Is everyone going to enjoy the wordplay today, or will some be saying the puzzle is 34 Across? Have an OREO.

This puzzle was sneaky good.  The themers weren‚Äôt obvious (at least not to me) and each one was its own aha moment.  My favorite, and the last to fall, was DRAGONSLAYER.  I also got a kick out of seeing RAP and EMO stacked atop each other (even though EMO wasn‚Äôt being used as a music genre in this case).  I had tried EMO as the mix tape genre, so I was amused to see it crop up right below where I had improperly inserted it.

I sometimes struggle with wordplay entries but these fell into place easily. Much easier than yesterday. 1:53 under my average as oppse to over my average. Was thinking regatta before relay race. Loved LOOTS and HAULS side by side

A number of Curry's puzzles were nominated for the Griddies and this one may well be, too, with its offbeat cluing (very fond of [Casting rod] - WAND) and that great pair of clues that led to RAP over EMO -- I wanted to put EMO for both clues! Dragonslayer and Catscan were also fantastic. It made me think of my all-time favorite youtube video: a cat sitting on a couch all by itself, watching the metal band Slayer on TV. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Mx1sN15C5rs It's only a minute long but every time I watch it, I laugh and laugh, without really knowing why.

I enjoyed today's puzzle.  Not often the theme can make you go "Ugh" but still seem awesome.

My original guess for the mixtape was EMO and that happened to be the right answer for the clue right beneath it.

Also one of those puzzles that didn't rely too much on proper nouns, super awkward phrasing or overly common fillers.  I rolled my eyes thinking the son of Seth would be ESAU again, turned out to be ENOS.
CATSCAN best answer ever
I had a big goofy smile on my face this entire solve. Definitely not SO LAME ‚Ä¶ even though we are teetering on the edge of ‚Äúdad joke‚Äù.

One of those puzzles where I struggle for 44 minutes thinking I‚Äôll never finish until suddenly the music comes on. I was tempted to do a lookup but glad I held out and solved with brute force. It‚Äôs more satisfying that way. The puns were okay. I did love CATSCAN and TURTLESHELL because they were kinda edgy, but the other two were CRINGE (the answer I kept coming back to before realizing it was SO LAME). I wish for once ADE would be clued as ‚ÄúNigerian musician King Sunny.‚Äù

at first i didnt quite understand why HORSESTABLE was a furniture item, and i was sure that SCARfED was correct. wasnt till i saw CHICKEfSTRIP that i was like Oh yeah okay. One of my favorite and fastest wednesdays in a while. 14:56

I loved the reparsing of the theme answers. None of them seemed obvious and each brought a smile as I figured it out. I enjoy jigsaw puzzles as well as crosswords, so I liked seeing EDGE PIECES and was surprised it was a debut! I saw a link between CLIPS and MAVS as nicknames for NBA teams. I had one MISSTEP with ScARFS before SNARFS. All in all a fantastic Wednesday. Thank you, Kevin.

Anybody else fill in "gorgon" before MEDUSA? It didn't last past the first crossing, but since MEDUSA was one of the Gorgons, and there was no hint that only one of the three was being referenced, it seemed right at the time.

I liked the puzzle, but here's a nit: to say an ash "goes down in flames" is tenuous. 

I WILL CONCEDE: Ashes "go down," yes, but only in the sense that nearly everything else on earth does. To the extent that it does, I'd wager it does so no more often (nor distinctively, nor dramatically, nor necessarily) than the average solid or liquid matter that has ever existed within earth's atmosphere. 

To put it another way, downward movement is nowhere close to necessary nor sufficient for establishing a definition of an ash. Nor would one ever consider mentioning such motion in any sensible definition. I get that crossword clues are not intended to establish an obvious or unmistakable 1:1 correlation between a clue and its answer, but i will die on the hill of saying a clue needs to winnow the field of possible answers further than (checks notes) **99.9% of all solids and liquids that have ever existed on or near earth or any other planet.**

If you response is to point out that I haven't mentioned the fact that ashes are, in fact, associated with fire. Of course, but by the present standard, it would be just as well to clue ASH with "fire sale," because ash is often sold on the open market. 

Or with "fire bug" because ashes can certainly bug people. Or with "fire blanket," because a coat of ash can form a blanket over surrounding areas.

But all of those clues would be terrible, and so is this one.

[Relatives in a sty] for PIGSKIN?

Fantastic clueing. 

(Go Seahawks!)

Granted, there is a question mark in the clue "Outlet store?" for 13D POWER. 

(But I hope this doesn't suggest that energy per time is actually stored in a wall outlet, because it isn't! Instead, energy is actually manufactured inside each powered device, by a new kind of battery based on a recently discovered archaea microorganism that eats light.)

Wow what a tight fun theme. I do think Kevin‚Äôs choices ended up being the best ones rather than his alternates‚ÄîBEARSPRAY is clever but PRAYER is really the noun; TOADSTOOL is a little stretchy; and Babe at a family reunion doesn‚Äôt convey the possessive. But the ones he included were terrific!
I had some odd misdirects today. I know enough about  sports to know David Justice‚Äôs domain is MLB (even if it was wrong) but not enough to know Nowotzki was on the MAVS not the CAVS. I had PEON before PLEB, EVADE before ELUDE (and no reason to think Vegas‚Äôs airport code doesn‚Äôt start with a V), and the usual ambiguity between SCARF and SNARF.  That and CATSEAT before CATSCAN and being mad that it didn‚Äôt follow the theme.
So this Wednesday was both a decent challenge and as much fun as a Thanksgiving party (or a TURKEYSHOOT as I like to say). Thanks Kevin!

Excellent puzzle, Kevin! My favorite was TURTLESHELL. Made me laugh out loud.
Sometimes I feel really in sync with a puzzle, so that even if it comes easily, it's still fun and satisfying-- this was one of those. Thanks! I have always loved dad jokes.
TURTLESHELL is absolutely incredible, one of my favorite single clues I've seen.

Liked the cluing for WAND and the grid placement under DRAGONSLAYER. Also limeade is vastly superior to lemonade.

As ever, go Gunners! Dreaming of May and the Treble.

Jesus... Monday/Tuesday clueing and a theme of groaners... This was one of the least satisfying Wednesday solves I have ever experienced at the NYT. What a letdown üòê

For a fascinating, modern look at the Medusa myth which reframes her as that victim and Perseus as the villain (if not quite a monster), check out the brilliant Natalie Haynes's "Pandora's Jar: Women in the Greek Myths."

Fun puzzle and great puns! üòÅ

Oh, some awesome punning, love it. Especially with the dad joke response in there. (And yes, turtle's hell was the gem.)

Skosh, the word, always bugs me, I guess knowing that it came to English from GIs in Japan (sukoshi = a bit) and somehow landed in the US without acknowledging that. At least "moose" (musume = daughter) didn't catch on for girl.

Totally ignored theme and just went about my business fueled by the effects of a long lunch extending into happy hour both with dear friends to celebrate my birthday and finishing with a Mojito and a slightly slower solve for a Wednesday. Happy to see OREO's reappearance which segues into cookies and somehow s'mores the Italian equivalent of which I discovered at aforementioned lunch where I chose the Pizza Pillows covered with cinnamon and Nutella. Bliss. Nice niggle-free puzzle - thanks.
This puzzle made the bull sigh.

Woolly court proceedings?

I thought this was lots of fun, and took me almost exactly my Wednesday average time. I had filled in several of the themed clues before clicking - trying to puzzle out PIGSKIN is what really brought it home for me.

commentBody: Apologies if I've missed it, but does this sort of wordplay, in which two different expressions are possible from the same conjoined word pair depending on how the words are split, have a name?

What a positively charming puzzle, I was smiling at my screen half the time!

As someone who tends to anthropomorphize my animal friends, I thought this was great. Loved them all. Coincidentally, in my rerun comics, this one came up today: https://www.gocomics.com/toomuchcoffeeman/2026/01/28

Just a great puzzle. It‚Äôs not often a crossword really makes me laugh, but TURTLESHELL got me. I enjoyed it so much that I‚Äôm willing to overlook the use of some fill words that I don‚Äôt love (OREO, EMO, PLEB).

Oh, bravo to the mind that came up with this wordplay theme ‚Äì never been done before.  I wouldn‚Äôt expect less from Kevin, whose {Pan in the butt] made 2025‚Äôs Clues of the Year list (answer in reply).  Also, good choice to tighten the theme by limiting it to animals.

Freshness in the grid as well, as every theme answer is not only an in-the-language phrase, but a NYT debut.

I like the PuzzPair¬©Ô∏è  of RELAY RACES and WAND, the lovely answers SKULK and UPSHOT, the rare-in-crosswords five-letter semordnilap (LOOTS), and how IT‚ÄôS ODD contradicts its clue number.  I also like the unintended airport code (ORD) sharing the box with the intended one (LAS).

But mostly I like the play of words in the theme, a ‚ÄúHah!‚Äù-heavy solve for me, the loudest coming at TURTLESHELL.

Your mood elevator was greatly appreciated, Kevin.  Thank you!

Paper solvers may be a bit puzzled by the start of your Tricky Clues comment on 60A. The clue in the paper doesn't have the  ‚úî; it has the work "Check."
Fun!

Typical slow start for me, but finally tumbling to the trick was the big turning point and that's always a nice touch. Thumbs up on this one. And... has it been done before? Yep - a Wednesday from August 7, 2002 by Randolph Ross. Some clues and answers in that one: "Insect's bedtime ritual?" BUGSPRAYERS "Sass from Elsie?" COWSLIP "Hammer for a hopper?" TOADSTOOL "Puss's food container?" CATSCAN "Rams, lambs and ewes?" SHEEPSKIN Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/7/2002&g=26&d=D I'm done. ....
HAZE seems to be the same thing as fog, although when I think of haze it's in the upper atmosphere. Maybe this is a regional thing?

A nice set of theme answers with varying degrees of difficulty.

To beat a dead horse:  Regarding ASH, once again some clarity and perhaps accuracy is sacrificed in the clue in order to be able to use a well-worn phrase in the clue.  Happens regularly; nothing to see here.

For those curious about how difficult others found today's puzzle:  Completed in 27% less time than average.

[Ascending my soapbox] You can share how easy/difficult a puzzle was quantitatively without revealing your actual time.  In fact, Telling me it took you 3 minutes less time than average does not give me a good idea of how easy the puzzle was for you.  Your average for this day could be 10 minutes or 60 minutes.  To compute relative degree of difficulty, subtract today's time from  average time and divide that result by average time.  For me that would be (21 - 29)/29 = -27%.  As you can see, I am not a fast solver, but I was able to complete today's puzzle significantly faster than usual.
OK. Easy. Nothing really stands out.

What a cute little theme! As a CT technologist, CATSCAN definitely made me laugh. Huge shoutout to TURTLESHELL also because that's hilarious. Loved this puzzle!

I doubt the existence of a RAP mixtape at all, let alone "many", as anyone who listens to that probably doesn't know what a tape was, and they certainly doesn't have the equipment to record or play back one.

I enjoyed this quite a bit and got a kick out of the theme; I chuckled more than once. Today seemed (relative to the day) easier than yesterday..finished around 40% under my average today.

Speaking of outlet stores, one of my first jobs was at Radio Shack, where instructions were to "sell more batteries!" Always good to have extra batteries around during these winter storms. Keep your lantern lit.
Very enjoyable and clever puzzle.  Who didn‚Äôt laugh at TURTLESHELL?

One more puzzle find. This one very unusual. A Sunday from December 10, 1995 by Jim Page with the title: "Clueless." And... there were a number of answer that did not have clues. Here are some examples (note the location). 21a: GAMBLERSCARDGAME 50a: STATECAPITALS 77a: TVSUNSETSTRIP 112a: FIFTYSIXTIMESTWO 76d: TROMBONES Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=12/10/1995&g=76&d=D ...

Oh ugh. So many nasty answers. PIGSKIN made MY skin crawl. So did DRAGONSLAYER AND TURTLESHELL. Such negativity we could live without. No, I did NOT like this puzzle.

Great puzzle. I successfully guessed the answers to the discarded clues in the constructor notes, except for #2 (Night vision goggles to help catch bugs?), which I had as FLYSPECKS. Doesn‚Äôt fit the theme perfectly, which gave me agita, but fun nonetheless!

That‚Äôs probably a sign of a successful theme ‚Äî gets the solver involved and the creative juices flowing. Loved it!

After about ten minutes of work, my puzzle struck me as an imperfect representation of the population density of the lower 48 United States held up to a mirror.  The West, fully populated, the East with mostly wide-open spaces.  

Cheated once by looking up mixtape, changed EMO to RAP, and RELAYRACES became an option. Worked out the right side of the dragon, chicken, cat and turtle clues, and the rest fell into place. 

Fun puzzle
I really appreciate how 34A preempts critique of the humor in the theme‚Ä¶ ;)

Good puzzle, imo

Personally, I‚Äôm glad two airport codes or two Spanish fillers weren‚Äôt featured in the same set of clues.

Very clever. 
I've never constructed a pun or play on words, so I'm in awe at those who can. 
I did think that a CHICKENSTRIP was something on a US fast-food menu. I had PIGlets at first, and I forgot CAN means a toilet.
A personal favorite for the month.  Reasonable clues and giggle-worthy wordplay.

Liked this one, though for some reason the theme seemed quite familiar. Not sure why, and in this case each themer began with an animal, which was nice.

TURTLE SHELL = TURTLE'S HELL was my favorite, and CAT SCAN = CATS "CAN" my least favorite.

Seemed just right for midweek, and very nicely made.

Speaking of how tricky it can be not having spaces, I could not figure out for the life of me what SOLAME meant. Even googled it to see if it was some new slang until it finally dawned on me. I felt SO LAME in that moment üòÖ

A nice, straightforward Wednesday offering. Unusually for me I ‚Äògot‚Äô the theme right away. Yay me. 

I‚Äôm with @Andrzej on the MEDUSA line. Monster or victim? Depends on your outlook, but I would class her character alongside women cast as witches. More sinned against than sinning.

Still floodbound here. We‚Äôre fine on our little hill, but surrounded by flooded fields and unable to get out of the village. Some of the village houses haven‚Äôt fared so well; they were fine until a couple of massive tractors sped through. The resulting bow waves flooded several houses. A couple of farmers on the larger farms are getting some angry calls. We have a name for the young lads who drive these behemoths at breakneck speed, but it‚Äôs definitely not emu friendly.

A lesson in parsing, eh?  
Usually, Kevin Curry's name causes a little frisson of anxiety, but in this case it morphed into something more akin to frustration... at least for a wee moment.  

Speaking of EDGE PIECES, I am still pecking away at the 1,000-piece puzzle, about 3-5 finds at a time, all alone--PhysDau not coming (horse show cancelled) and DHubby (never a big fan) unwilling... but I did find the lone missing edge piece finally!  Now down to the dark, dark and the white, white pieces.  Slog, slog.

It has warmed up; our part of the state has been spared, largely.  The counties to the north are in a bad way.  This one was serious!

All y'all stay safe and warm.  Beware of the ice.

@Sam

Re 32A, I took it to be an abbreviation for ‚Äúordinal‚Äù ‚Äî versus ‚Äúcardinal‚Äù numbers.
I laughed out loud at TURTLESHELL
Nice puzzle with a clever theme.  Only nitpick is HAZE as a driving hazard.  Fog, sleet, hail, ice I can see but not haze.  Need to think through the clues a little better.
A lot of "ahas" and smiles today. Perfect, fun Wednesday!
Cute but sloppy puzzle. The theme was tough to figure out but most of the crosses were easy enough to figure it out‚Ä¶ To me the whole NE corner was poorly clued. Maybe just me though.
Fun puzzle, even if it was a bit too easy for a Wednesday. I enjoy wordplay like that found in this puzzle.

I often wonder what exactly is defined as "sparkling fill," or other such compliments for a happily crafted crossword. This, this is that definition. It started with 6D, then 13D, 30A...and by then I had discovered the theme and was smitten.  nO LAME puzzle, this.
So good!
Excellent midweek puzzle! Very clever and a pleasant solve overall.
Turtle‚Äôs hell‚Äîbravo 1000 times

Loved this.  Smiled at every one.  Thank you.

And... one more puzzle find. A Wednesday from May 4, 2011 by Jeff Chen. The reveal in that one was: "Maneuver required five times to finish this puzzle." UTURN And then the theme answers (all down answers) ABLEWASIER ROTA DEIF MADAMI AIBOHP Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=5/4/2011&g=7&d=D ....
I filled it in without much trouble, but had to come to the column to understand what the theme is.
A dad-joke puzzle made for a fun Wednesday as we hack our way out of the ice in RVA...which is literally a citywide ice rink.  But nothing compred to TN and MS!  What a week!
On the easier side for a Wednesday, but I loved the theme clues! They definitely got a chuckle, or at least a smile
Welcome back, Sam!  Missed your off-beat ability to make me laugh!  As with ‚ÄúOvercomplication? Ambiguity? Misdirection? Don‚Äôt threaten us with a good time!‚Äù Or maybe do!
I think this was my favorite ever crossword! Thank you so much
TURTLESHELL was my favorite answer in a long time!
What a fun puzzle!
Love this theme! One of the best in a long time, very clever!
Oh this was just terrific! Loved it!

This was probably on the easy side, I got it without too much trouble (20 mins is fast for me on a Wed). Good theme, cleverly done without being overwrought or just pointless.
I actually got the theme after getting two of the theme answers, which is unusual for me. I think using a couple of shorter answers for the theme meant that the rest of the clues don‚Äôt have to be battered into shape to fit in, which allows for better answers and clues.

Liked this one.

I did look at ‚Äúcookie with about 50 calories‚Äù and think how am I supposed to know that, but three months of these things kicked in pretty fast.

For once it was beneficial to be a Scandinavian and not local. Power happens to be an outlet store chain for household appliances and electronics and it operates in Norway, Finland and Denmark (only). So that cue was very easy and "obvious" to me. For once!
Yeah, it was kind of easy, but so what? It was so much fun. I chuckled quite a bit as I solved it.

I really enjoyed this puzzle and the fun wordplay! 

But‚Ä¶ outlet store? = POWER‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs a big stretch. Outlets do not store power lol. 

Also, I have not heard anyone say ‚Äúsnarfs down‚Äù before, so that threw me off for a little. I have only heard and have used ‚Äúscarf‚Äù. As in ‚ÄúI just scarfed down my food‚Äù. Apparently both are used though.
This kind of wordplay is right up my alley. Thanks for the fun!

And one more puzzle find. I'll re-post this tomorrow. A Sunday from July 3, 1994 by A.J. Santora with the title: "Overcrowding." Some theme clues and answers; "Newsman in the Sahara?" SUDANRATHER "Canal zone film favorites?" PANAMAANDPAKETTLE "Actor who craved goulash?" HUNGARYCOOPER And some other theme answers: ARGENTINATURNER BOHEMIAFARROW BOLIVIANEWTONJOHN SENEGALGORE ETHIOPIAZADORA NORMANDYROONEY AMERICAJONG Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/3/1994&g=50&d=A ...
Great puzzle. No complaints. 18:56! One of my best times for a Wednesday.

@Ned S
Thinking about your lengthy rant has actually led me to the conclusion that the clue is even stronger than when I solved it in the puzzle (though I still don‚Äôt mean that it‚Äôs particularly memorable or remarkable, simply fine).

‚ÄúI get that crossword clues are not intended to establish an obvious or unmistakable 1:1 correlation between a clue and its answer, but i will die on the hill of saying a clue needs to winnow the field of possible answers further than (checks notes) **99.9% of all solids and liquids that have ever existed on or near earth or any other planet.**‚Äù

Pure combustion of hydrogen and oxygen produces only water vapor (i.e., water in a gaseous, not liquid or solid, state). Pure combustion of a hydrocarbon like methane additionally produces carbon dioxide (again, a gas in ordinary conditions). Combustion of something more complex but largely carbon-based, like wood, a cigarette, or a candle wick and wax, will additionally produce various volatile gases and *solid residues*. By definition, ash is ‚Äúthe powdery residue, composed chiefly of earthy or mineral particles, left after the combustion of any substance‚Äù (per Oxford).

In other words, the clue *is* pretty much exactly a 1:1 dictionary definition of the answer, ASH.

‚ÄúIf you [sic] response is to point out that I haven't mentioned the fact that ashes are, in fact, associated with fire. Of course, but by the present standard‚Ä¶‚Äù

You haven‚Äôt defined this nebulous standard, so I can‚Äôt follow your logic.
@Scott  You're new here, aren't you?
@Ned S I‚Äôm on Ned‚Äôs side on this.

@Nick
I still don‚Äôt understand. Ash is, of course, a product of fire, but I still can‚Äôt see the ‚Äúgoes down‚Äù part. The volume of ash goes up during a fire, and a significant percentage of ash particles are of small enough aerodynamic diameter that they float away from the fire, so may not go down locally. If the clue is merely saying that ash settles after a fire, I agree it is weak.

@Sam Lyons

Quite litteral.

Speaking of which, I wasted my reading time yesterday searching through the Project Gutenberg text of Der Zauberberg to check on some of the quotes in my notes from the L-P translation.

It only identifies Chapter breaks and my German isn't good enough to find the precise sentences I was looking for among the dense paragraphs.  (I did see that the description of the harbor cranes as elephants was as Mann wrote it.)

Anyhoo, I'm pressing on.  Settembrini has just "explained" to Hans that Nature is opposed to the Mind and is "mystical and evil".  He notes that Voltaire fumed against Nature for the great Lisbon earthquake.  Hans stands his ground, for once.

Next up:  Hans and cousin in the garden after lunch.

@Al in P. Ah yes, Voltaire took the Lisbon earthquake quite personally: ‚ÄúOh wretched man, earth-fated to be cursed; Abyss of plagues, and miseries the worst! Horrors on horrors, griefs on griefs must show, That man's the victim of unceasing woe, And lamentations which inspire my strain, Prove that philosophy is false and vain.‚Äù Voltaire, he of ancient Gauls for ancestors who ‚Äúshot arrows against the heavens,‚Äù goes on in this vein for about 15 pages. Talk about rabbit holes: When I first read that line about the Gauls, I scoured Strabo, Pausanias, and co. to see where Mann may have got the myth. I finally concluded he must have got it from an illustration to an 1881 book by Jos√© Coroleu, Las Supersticiones De La Humanidad, which was, I admit, a letdown. As I recall, in the chapter you‚Äôre on, that exchange between Settembrini and Hans is such a masterful metaphor for how the intellectual inertia of most of society reacts to the finest humanistic ideas our civilization has ever put forth. (You just have to make allowances for Mann‚Äôs orientalism. He was a man of his era, like anyone else.) Re. the translation. Yes, it‚Äôs much too loose to hunt down side-by-side comparisons most of the time. Here‚Äôs a journal article that you mind find interesting, though I should warn you it‚Äôs not by a fan of L-P: https://tinyurl.com/55xyr5km I‚Äôd skip down to the bottom of p. 3 to start and take a look at a couple of pages. It‚Äôll give you a feel for the version you‚Äôre reading.

@The X-Phile

I agree with your framing of Voltaire‚Äôs target being Leibnizian optimism rather than Nature per se. In the book, though, Settembrini‚Äôs invocation of Voltaire is doing something more symbolic: Nature refers at once to the ‚Äúmystical and evil‚Äù forces of disease overtaking his own body (Mann has staged illness as epistemology in the novel) and, more abstractly, to what Enlightenment reason sets itself against. 

What‚Äôs interesting is that the character of Settembrini uses Voltaire as an anti-Nature witness,
but Mann knows that Voltaire after Lisbon no longer trusted either Nature *or* Reason to make suffering intelligible.

Mann seems less interested in adjudicating Voltaire than in showing how even secular humanism preserves a quasi-theological structure‚Äîwith Reason inheriting the role of Providence.

@Sam Lyons @The X-Phile

Here's a superficial reply to the article.  I just want to get an acknowledgement in before today's comments get swept aside.

I think Simon underestimates the modern reader.
A smattering of knowledge of German myth and folklore is not all that rare.  The tales of the brothers Grimm and Wagner's operas have had quite some exposure even among those with no direct experience with the works themselves.

Some of the suggested translations replace specifics with generalities.  "Fuss and bother" for 
"Stops and formalities"  because Hans would know what happened on border-crossing trains does not mean that the English reader would.  Perhaps even Germans in these days of the EU and Schengen protocols would not.  Similarly, "dissipate or erode" instead of "cut up" does not describe the inconvenience of interruptions and inconveniences along the route.

Some examples seem to be matters of taste and are no big deal.  "Grubby" vs "Soiled". "Chillblained" vs "Frozen". "Bony" vs "Withered".

The two long discussions of A Soldier and Brave
and The Lindentree are special cases of underestimating the reader's familiarity with either Goethe or Schubert.  I will admit to not knowing the associations for Hippe.  Wasn't that the name of an Admiral or General or maybe a battleship?  üòâ

@Dan

Yeah this was my least favorite clue. Does it mean the outlet is a litte 7-11 with shelves full of electrons? Is water from my "faucet store?" Even with the question mark it's a klunker.

@Dan
Agreed. I would have preferred it clued as ‚ÄúOutlet supply‚Äù
@SP after reading your comment, I realized I actually had two MISSTEPS as I also started with EvaDE before ELUDE in addition to my ScARFS before SNARFS.

@SP

Did we solve the same puzzle? For me this solved like a Tuesday, at best, and one with one of the most groany themes I have ever encountered at the NYT.
@SP don‚Äôt worry i spent the entire solve thinking 11D must be some obscure US word for a tug-o-war until I got the crossings. Scoff was also an option between scarf and snarf.

@Andrzej

Well I like groany puns so that was a plus; and it wasn‚Äôt so difficult overall, but those initial wrong guesses did make this chewier for me than the average Wednesday.
@SP also had CAVS and EVADE and yachtRACES

@Matt

Actually I‚Äôll pipe in and say I didn‚Äôt like the clue. ‚ÄúNot hard‚Äù would work and I get trying to be cute but ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not hard‚Äù really implies a noun not an adjective. I finally decided that ‚Äúit‚Äù means ‚Äúthe word ‚Äòsoft‚Äô‚Äù ‚Äîbut I think that a bit of a stretch even as a misdirection so thumbs down for me on it.

@Matt

The groaners and simplistic clues left me so deflated I don't have it in me to be crass üò¢

@Andrzej As I was solving this one, I was thinking: Andrzej is going to hate this. Lo and behold, yours was the first comment displayed when I entered the forum. Ha! 
I‚Äôm easy and corny so I loved the puzzle, but I was ‚Äúdelighted‚Äù to see your review as predicted as well as the alternate Medusa reference. That‚Äôs what makes this fun!

@M. Biggen

I wonder what makes people love or hate groaners. Is it about the culture we grew up in? Personal preferences? Something else? For as long as I can remember I have enjoyed off-beat and dark humor.
@Andrzej hey Zeus - ye flippin' gods! Wasn't that bad was it? Maybe setting up a false sense of security before a heinous Thurday, perhaps?

@Andrzej I thought the puzzle was at par for Wednesday and elegantly thought out. Not particularly my thing but it wasn‚Äôt 34A. It was good. Re Medusa Haynes did a very good series on the BBC. https://podcasts.apple.com/de/podcast/natalie-haynes-stands-up-for-the-classics/id1495971324?i=1000522541040

@Andrzej
As is so often the case, I agree with you. I found this puzzle to be a yawner. After doing the puzzle for so many decades, I must have seen this trick many times.

@Andrzej O you are not being a curmudgeon here! I didn't like it either. Maybe It's because I keep watching all those animal shows on the telly. This puzzle just had a lot of ICK in it regarding animals.

I would like to read about Pandora's Jar. One of my favorite characters from Greek mythology is Penelope, Odysseus's wife. 

Penelope told the suitors who demanded that she accept one of them to replace long-gone Odysseus that she would re-marry when she finished the tapestry she was weaving. Every day she would weave it all day, then stay up at night un-weaving it. It sounds like the lot of a lot of American women today, maybe, hitting that glass ceiling, etc.

For two great movies about women's struggles (in the workplace) today, check out North Country (starring Charlize Theon) and Lilly (with Patricia Clarkson). Both are based on true stories.

My absolute favorite female in Greek myths is Daphne. You can check out her struggles with Appollo in Edith Hamilton's classic book "Mythology."
@Andrzej You are one hard fella to please.

@Ken

Don't I know it!

@Andrzej, I was going to comment that I thought it was way too easy, as I look forward to the middle of the week when the puzzles start getting harder, typically on Wednesday. (I decided not to comment, because it seemed I was in minority.) I finished in the single digits, at 40% of my usual time, which was a bit of a letdown.

But for me, the punny theme answers made up for it and left me with several smiles along the way. My favorite was TURTLESHELL at 56A! I loved seeing all the witty additions in the comments.
@Jill (@Andrzej) p.s. Thank you for the reminder about Pandora‚Äôs Jar. I have that in my Kindle library, lingering at about 75% progress. Loved that book and will pick it up again!

@Jill

It's well worth it üôÇ

Hay, with tack like that you'll have a hors d'oeuvres the moon.  It deserves it, because when it reins, it shines.

@Mike

That‚Äôs a filly gift, but the bridle love it. It‚Äôs all she‚Äôs wanted since the groom popped equestrian.
@Mike Your puns somehow give me both a nagging doubt and a galloping heart rate

@Mike
Your rein continues...

@jes

But, countless English words came from other languages without acknowledgement (whatever that means). Does it bug you because it was borrowed by GIs? I don't get it.
@jes I speak Japanese but had never heard of "skosh" in English! I got that clue through the crosses but didn't really understand, thanks for explainingüòÇüòÇ

@Bill in Yokohama
I don't quite know why it bugs me, for some reason the usage seemed crass to me. My own problem, I know! Some Neurospiciness or other.
I am mostly ok with loan words ( I loved the ones brought into Japanese when I studied that decades ago, like "remocon" for remote control, for example.) And often these are modern things stuffed into old languages that need to be reshaped to accommodate. 
Other prickly ones for me are the short-style of imported words into Swedish, where I live now after a lifetime of Californian English and Spanish: El for electricity, bil for automobile. I just can't hear or read "El bil" correctly. Or the megastore El Giganten, gets me every time.

@G you realize smog = smoke + fog right?

@Jason

Smog's meaning has changed to visible air pollution. For example Denver seldom has fog, but plenty of smog.

@Dale M

Yes, Los Angeles sits in a kind of geographic "bowl" caused by the nearby mountains (and maybe the winds off the ocean). The smog just sits there.

@Jim 
Shouldn't you also test for significance, and provide confidence intervals, before we jump to any conclusions about whether this was an easier puzzle for you or not?

@Esmerelda

LOL! Nice!

@Esmerelda

But we aren't dealing with sampling here are we?  My average is not based on a sample of the population, it is based on having all the population data.  My time for today is not a sample of the population, it is the population.  Does that make sense?

@Jim
Yes. I didn't think of that!

@Esmerelda

No worries.  People seemed to like your answer.

@Jim
My answer was only half tongue-in-cheek. I actually do enjoy and learn a lot from the nerdy math/statistics comments.
@Esmerelda. Love your approach!

@Jim

I don't keep the timer on or review stats regularly.

But I've always thought there is significantly more to a "hard" puzzle than the time it took to complete it.  It's how much of a mental workout it gave, how much surprise and delight it provided, how many twists and turns and unexpected wordplay it took.  This can all happen quite quickly and still be a difficult puzzle.  A case in point is the one in my occasional signature here, which I completed more quickly than I would have liked.

____________________
